elements.content: Three azido-bridged Co2+ complexes with square, honeycomb, and Kagomé layered structures were synthesized and structurally characterized. Crystallization solvents are found to be critical in generating the observed topologies. These structurally related complexes are of significance in studying two-dimensional antiferromagnetism and geometric frustration.
elements.clean_text: Three azido-bridged Co2+ complexes with square, honeycomb, and Kagomé layered structures were synthesized and structurally characterized. Crystallization solvents are found to be critical in generating the observed topologies. These structurally related complexes are of significance in studying two-dimensional antiferromagnetism and geometric frustration.

elements.content: Two-dimensional (2D) spin-half antiferromagnets have generated a great deal of recent interest because of their fascinating magnetic properties and their pertinence to high-temperature superconductivity and spin chirality. Among various possible 2D lattice structures, the geometrically frustrated Kagomé lattice, characterized by interlaced triangles whose lattice points each have four neighboring points, occupies a special position. Substances with an ideal Kagomé structure cannot gain magnetic ordering even at zero temperature as a result of strong quantum fluctuations originated from geometrical frustration. As such, they represent ideal candidates for the study of magnetic frustration phenomenon. However, most magnetic studies of Kagomé structured materials have been with jarosite KFe3(SO4)2(OH)6 and its analogues.
elements.clean_text: Two-dimensional (2D) spin-half antiferromagnets have generated a great deal of recent interest because of their fascinating magnetic properties and their pertinence to high-temperature superconductivity and spin chirality. Among various possible 2D lattice structures, the geometrically frustrated Kagomé lattice, characterized by interlaced triangles whose lattice points each have four neighboring points, occupies a special position. Substances with an ideal Kagomé structure cannot gain magnetic ordering even at zero temperature as a result of strong quantum fluctuations originated from geometrical frustration. As such, they represent ideal candidates for the study of magnetic frustration phenomenon. However, most magnetic studies of Kagomé structured materials have been with jarosite KFe3(SO4)2(OH)6 and its analogues.

elements.content: Manipulation of metal−ligand coordination and other intermolecular interactions in the context of supramolecular construction offers great prospects of generating structurally unique architectures, including Kagomé lattices. Zaworotko and co-workers reported the first crystal engineered Kagomé lattice whose lattice vertexes are occupied by paramagnetic dicopper(II) tetracarboxylate spin pairs. However, the Cu2+ ions within the metal dimer are coupled antiferromagnetically, and the bridges between these dimers are too long to allow effective magnetic coupling. A scant few other Kagomé-type coordination or organic radical networks have since appeared in the literature, but preparation of such uniquely structured materials, especially those featuring strong antiferromagnetically coupled spins, remains a challenge.
elements.clean_text: Manipulation of metal-ligand coordination and other intermolecular interactions in the context of supramolecular construction offers great prospects of generating structurally unique architectures, including Kagomé lattices. Zaworotko and co-workers reported the first crystal engineered Kagomé lattice whose lattice vertexes are occupied by paramagnetic dicopper(II) tetracarboxylate spin pairs. However, the Cu2+ ions within the metal dimer are coupled antiferromagnetically, and the bridges between these dimers are too long to allow effective magnetic coupling. A scant few other Kagomé-type coordination or organic radical networks have since appeared in the literature, but preparation of such uniquely structured materials, especially those featuring strong antiferromagnetically coupled spins, remains a challenge.

elements.content: In this report, we present a new example of a Kagomé-type coordination network constructed from Co2+ ions and azido ligands. The Kagomé layer is further linked by bridging meso-α,β-bi(4-pyridyl) glycol (bpg) ligands to generate a 3D framework, wherein crystallization solvent molecules, presumably assisting in the formation of the observed structure, are found interacting with the bridging ligand. Interestingly, simply by changing the solvent used, two other networks, one of azido-bridged Co2+ squares and the other of honeycombs, were also obtained. This series of complexes thus provide a good system for comparative structural and magnetic studies.
elements.clean_text: In this report, we present a new example of a Kagomé-type coordination network constructed from Co2+ ions and azido ligands. The Kagomé layer is further linked by bridging meso-α,β-bi(4-pyridyl) glycol (bpg) ligands to generate a 3D framework, wherein crystallization solvent molecules, presumably assisting in the formation of the observed structure, are found interacting with the bridging ligand. Interestingly, simply by changing the solvent used, two other networks, one of azido-bridged Co2+ squares and the other of honeycombs, were also obtained. This series of complexes thus provide a good system for comparative structural and magnetic studies.

elements.content: The three complexes are of the general formula Co(N3)2(bpg)·S n (1, S = nothing; 2, S = DMSO, n = 1; 3, S = DMF, n = 4/3) and were synthesized by reacting NaN3 with CoCl2 and bpg in a 2:1:1 molar ratio in MeOH/H2O (1), DMSO/H2O (2), and DMF/H2O (3), respectively. All are 3D coordination frameworks featuring different 2D cobalt-azido layers bridged by bpg ligands. Specifically, Co2+ in the square-structured layer in complex 1 is octahedrally coordinated with six N atoms, four from the equivalent end-to-end (EE) azides (Co−Nazide = 2.113 and 2.142 Å) and two from trans-bpg (Co−Nbpg = 2.185 Å) (Figure a). The 2D square layer lies in the bc plane with an intralayer Co−Co distance of 5.932 Å (Figure b). The longer axes of the slightly distorted octahedra noticeably tilt toward each other. Lack of an inversion center between the EE azido-bridged Co2+ ions due to this distortion suggests the possibility of 1 being a spin-canted weak ferromagnet. The bpg ligands crisscross to bridge at two different angles relative to the sheets (Figure c), leading to an overall network topology previously reported for Cd(CN)2(pyrazine). The shortest Co−Co distance between adjacent layers is 13.6 Å.
elements.clean_text: The three complexes are of the general formula Co(N3)2(bpg)⋅S n  (1, S = nothing; 2, S = DMSO, n = 1; 3, S = DMF, n = 4/3) and were synthesized by reacting NaN3 with CoCl2 and bpg in a 2:1:1 molar ratio in MeOH/H2O (1), DMSO/H2O (2), and DMF/H2O (3), respectively. All are 3D coordination frameworks featuring different 2D cobalt-azido layers bridged by bpg ligands. Specifically, Co2+ in the square-structured layer in complex 1 is octahedrally coordinated with six N atoms, four from the equivalent end-to-end (EE) azides (Co-Nazide = 2.113 and 2.142 Å) and two from trans-bpg (Co-Nbpg = 2.185 Å) (Figure a). The 2D square layer lies in the bc plane with an intralayer Co-Co distance of 5.932 Å (Figure b). The longer axes of the slightly distorted octahedra noticeably tilt toward each other. Lack of an inversion center between the EE azido-bridged Co2+ ions due to this distortion suggests the possibility of 1 being a spin-canted weak ferromagnet. The bpg ligands crisscross to bridge at two different angles relative to the sheets (Figure c), leading to an overall network topology previously reported for Cd(CN)2(pyrazine). The shortest Co-Co distance between adjacent layers is 13.6 Å.

elements.content: Structure of1:  (a) the local coordination environment of Co2+; (b) the square layer bridged by EE azide; (c) the 3D network bridged by bpg.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of1: (a) the local coordination environment of Co2+; (b) the square layer bridged by EE azide; (c) the 3D network bridged by bpg.

elements.content: In complex 2, the Co2+-bridging azido ligands adopt two kinds of bridging modes, EE, as in the case of 1, and EO (end-on), leading to a 2D honeycomb layer along the ab plane (Figure ). Each of the Co2+ ions is coordinated by six N atoms, four from the azido ligands (Co−Nazide = 2.134 and 2.158 Å) and two from bpg ligands (Co−Nbpg = 2.173 Å) (Figure a). Intralayer Co−Co distances are 3.341 and 6.313 Å, respectively, for EO- and EE-bridged pairs. The angle of Co−N EO −Co is 101.33°, propitious to ferromagnetic exchange between the involved Co2+ centers. If the two ferromagnetically coupled Co2+ ions are treated as one node, this honeycomb layer turns into a square one. Similar to 1, spin-canting may occur as a result of the absence of an inversion center between the dimeric nodes. The layers are connected by bpg ligands to generate a 3D structure, wherein disordered DMSO molecules are hydrogen bonded to the bpg ligands (Figure S1). The shortest interlayer Co−Co distance is 13.4 Å, similar to the corresponding value found in 1 (Figure c). Both the square and honeycomb structures are new for the Co2+−N3 - system, though they have been observed for other metals.
elements.clean_text: In complex 2, the Co2+-bridging azido ligands adopt two kinds of bridging modes, EE, as in the case of 1, and EO (end-on), leading to a 2D honeycomb layer along the ab plane (Figure ). Each of the Co2+ ions is coordinated by six N atoms, four from the azido ligands (Co-Nazide = 2.134 and 2.158 Å) and two from bpg ligands (Co-Nbpg = 2.173 Å) (Figure a). Intralayer Co-Co distances are 3.341 and 6.313 Å, respectively, for EO- and EE-bridged pairs. The angle of Co-N EO -Co is 101.33°, propitious to ferromagnetic exchange between the involved Co2+ centers. If the two ferromagnetically coupled Co2+ ions are treated as one node, this honeycomb layer turns into a square one. Similar to 1, spin-canting  may occur as a result of the absence of an inversion center between the dimeric nodes. The layers are connected by bpg ligands to generate a 3D structure, wherein disordered DMSO molecules are hydrogen bonded to the bpg ligands (Figure S1). The shortest interlayer Co-Co distance is 13.4 Å, similar to the corresponding value found in 1 (Figure c). Both the square and honeycomb structures are new for the Co2+-N3 - system, though they have been observed for other metals.

elements.content: Structure of2:  (a) the local environment of Co2+; (b) the honeycomb layer bridged by EE and EO azide; (c) the 3D structure bridged by bpg.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure of2: (a) the local environment of Co2+; (b) the honeycomb layer bridged by EE and EO azide; (c) the 3D structure bridged by bpg.

elements.content: Complex 3 is the most interesting one of the three. There are two unique Co2+ centers (Co1 and Co2), as indicated in Figure a. Each is coordinated with six N atoms, two from trans-bpg ligands and four from azido ligands. The metric values of Co−N bonds are comparable to those observed for 1 and 2. The azido ligands link the Co2+ ions in the EE fashion, affording along the bc plane a novel Kagomé layer featuring vertex-sharing triangles (Figure b). The wavy Kagomé layers are bridged by bpg ligands to generate a 3D framework whose hexagonal channels are filled by DMF molecules (Figure S2). Like DMSO in 2, DMF molecules are hydrogen bonded to the hydroxyl groups of the bpg ligands. The Co−Co separations within a particular triangle are close to one another at 5.776, 6.084, and 5.981 Å. This slight distortion from an ideal triangle is expected to influence the magnetic property of the complex as it lowers the symmetry of the metal centers, leading potentially to long-range ordering.
elements.clean_text: Complex 3 is the most interesting one of the three. There are two unique Co2+ centers (Co1 and Co2), as indicated in Figure a. Each is coordinated with six N atoms, two from trans-bpg ligands and four from azido ligands. The metric values of Co-N bonds are comparable to those observed for 1 and 2. The azido ligands link the Co2+ ions in the EE fashion, affording along the bc plane a novel Kagomé layer featuring vertex-sharing triangles (Figure b). The wavy Kagomé layers are bridged by bpg ligands to generate a 3D framework whose hexagonal channels are filled by DMF molecules (Figure S2). Like DMSO in 2, DMF molecules are hydrogen bonded to the hydroxyl groups of the bpg ligands. The Co-Co separations within a particular triangle are close to one another at 5.776, 6.084, and 5.981 Å. This slight distortion from an ideal triangle is expected to influence the magnetic property of the complex as it lowers the symmetry of the metal centers, leading potentially to long-range ordering.

elements.content: Structure of3:  (a) the local environment of Co1 and Co2; (b) the Kagomé layer bridged by EE azide; (c) the 3D structure bridged by bpg.
elements.clean_text: 3  Structure of3: (a) the local environment of Co1 and Co2; (b) the Kagomé layer bridged by EE azide; (c) the 3D structure bridged by bpg.

elements.content: Tilting of adjacent coordination octahedra of Co2+ in 3 may also affect its magnetic property. As in 1, this tilting allows the Dzyaloshinsky−Moriya interaction between Co2+ ions to occur; such interactions are believed to be largely responsible for the spin-canted long-range ordering of jarosite. However, complex 3 may be a better 2D magnetic system because even the shortest interlayer Co−Co distance is 13.5 Å, significantly longer than the corresponding value of 6.7 Å found in jarosite.
elements.clean_text: Tilting of adjacent coordination octahedra of Co2+ in 3 may also affect its magnetic property. As in 1, this tilting allows the Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya interaction between Co2+ ions to occur; such interactions are believed to be largely responsible for the spin-canted long-range ordering of jarosite. However, complex 3 may be a better 2D magnetic system because even the shortest interlayer Co-Co distance is 13.5 Å, significantly longer than the corresponding value of 6.7 Å found in jarosite.

elements.content: Preliminary magnetic measurements were carried out for 1 − 3 (χT(T) and χ-1(T) for 1 − 3 and χac(T) for 3, Figure S6−9). Fitting of the χ-1−T using the Curie−Weiss law gives the Curie constant C = 3.25, 3.76, and 4.05 cm3 mol-1 K and the Weiss constant θ = −54.1, −26.6, and −165.8 K for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. All three complexes show apparent antiferromagnetic coupling. Complexes 1 and 2 are weak ferromagnets as a result of spin canting with T N at about 10 K. For 3, the sharp peaks in χT and χac at about 16 K suggest a weak-ferromagnet state below T N = 16 K. The observed slightly frequency-dependent hump at about 9.5 K in χac for 3 suggests a re-entered magnetically disordered spin-glass state. The large |θ|/T N value (10) for 3 indicates strong frustration, as is expected in a Kagomé lattice. Thus, complex 3 provides a good molecule-based system to investigate the spin frustration phenomenon in a more isolated Kagomé lattice. Detailed magnetic studies of 1 − 3 are in progress, and the results will be reported soon.
elements.clean_text: Preliminary magnetic measurements were carried out for 1 - 3 (χT(T) and χ-1(T) for 1 - 3 and χac(T) for 3, Figure S6-9). Fitting of the χ-1-T using the Curie-Weiss law gives the Curie constant C = 3.25, 3.76, and 4.05 cm3 mol-1 K and the Weiss constant θ = -54.1, -26.6, and -165.8 K for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. All three complexes show apparent antiferromagnetic coupling. Complexes 1 and 2 are weak ferromagnets as a result of spin canting with T  N  at about 10 K. For 3, the sharp peaks in χT and χac at about 16 K suggest a weak-ferromagnet state below T  N  = 16 K. The observed slightly frequency-dependent hump at about 9.5 K in χac for 3 suggests a re-entered magnetically disordered spin-glass state. The large |θ|/T  N  value (10) for 3 indicates strong frustration, as is expected in a Kagomé lattice.  Thus, complex 3 provides a good molecule-based system to investigate the spin frustration phenomenon in a more isolated Kagomé lattice. Detailed magnetic studies of 1 - 3 are in progress, and the results will be reported soon.

elements.content: Crystal data (CIFs); syntheses, more structure figures, XRD patterns of all compounds; preliminary magnetic results of 1 − 3. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title: Solvent-Tuned Azido-Bridged Co2+ Layers:  Square, Honeycomb, and Kagomé
